Award.AwardTitle: Fostering Successful Innovative Large-Scale, Distributed Science and Engineering Projects through Integrated Collaboration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Large-scale, innovative science and engineering requires collaboration across geographically-distributed, multidisciplinary teams; however, it is very difficult for projects to maintain intellectual cohesion, tight coordination, and integration necessary to manage scalable ?virtual? work that is distributed.

The goal of this project is to help teams to succeed - maximizing efficiency, effectiveness, and innovativeness. This proposal is to develop the capacity for leaders of Centers, Institutes, Labs and other collaborations to plan and pursue transformative research agendas in order to truly create breakthroughs in smart and connected health, cyberphysical systems, smart cities, cybersecurity, big data, environmental sustainability, and across the domains of basic research. Training in design and management of such collaborations will be provided and tools and techniques will be developed. This work will draw on lessons learned from organization science to develop a customized curriculum to help large-scale science and engineering teams effectively and efficiently collaborate at this scale. Using the developed materials, the first of a series of workshops targeting potential principle investigators interested in large-scale Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE)-related projects will be conducted in the spring of 2016.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Addressing the grand challenges of science and engineering requires expertise drawn from multiple disciplines and involves researchers who may not be in the same physical location. It involves the organization and leadership of innovative large-scale science and engineering enterprises. However, many science and engineering researchers are not well-versed in the organizational practices that would enable them to effectively lead intellectually integrated, interdiciplinary collaborations that are operationally distributed.

This project involved drawing on lessons from organization science and on effective large-scale science enterprises to develop and execute a pilot workshop on leading such larger-scale research enterprises. The pilot was held on May 5-6, 2017 in Arlington, Virginia, at the NSF facility. Participants included science and engineering researchers involved with researcher funded by the Computer and Information Science and Engineering Directorate of NSF.

The workshop involved lessons from (1) existing research; (2) what exemplar projects are doing; and (3) useful practices from their peers.In drawing on lessons from organization science to help science and engineering researchers lead larger-scale distributed enterprises, topics included strategic management, stakeholder alignment, collaboration planning, and data management. Exemplar projects included presentations from MIT's Center for Bits and Atoms, and the Rennaissance Computing Institute of UNC Chapel Hill / Duke. There were a variety of activities and discussions where participants were able to interact and learn from each other.

Participant evaluations were overwhelmingly positive, and participant provided suggestions for future workshops.
